review.title: Approximating solution structure of the Weighted Sentence Alignment problem
review.abstract: We study the complexity of approximating solution structure of the bijective weighted sentence alignment problem of DeNero and Klein (2008). In particular, we consider the complexity of finding an alignment that has a significant overlap with an optimal alignment. We discuss ways of representing the solution for the general weighted sentence alignment as well as phrases-to-words alignment problem, and show that computing a string which agrees with the optimal sentence partition on more than half (plus an arbitrarily small polynomial fraction) positions for the phrases-to-words alignment is NP-hard. For the general weighted sentence alignment we obtain such bound from the agreement on a little over 2/3 of the bits. Additionally, we generalize the Hamming distance approximation of a solution structure to approximating it with respect to the edit distance metric, obtaining similar lower bounds.

sections.heading: 1.2 Our results
sections.text: In this paper, we analyze the complexity of approaching the solution structure of the weighted sentence alignment problem (WSA), especially its variant in which phrases in the source sentence match words in the target sentence (PWSA problem). We show that for PWSA, even if the weight function is limited to {0, 1} values, an alignment is calculated that matches an optimum of at least n / 2 + n, links are NP hard, where n is the length of the source sentence. Moreover, the hardness stems from the problem of partitioning the source sentence into phrases: We show how to modify the NP hardness proof so that the optimal alignment can be recovered directly from such a partition. Specifically, we define a compact solution representation for this problem to be a binary string that encloses the positions of the phrase boundaries, and show that the optimum alignment of a partition can be retrieved so that the hardness of such a partition can be changed.
